Award.AwardTitle: Mathematics of Energy Markets & Differential Games, Financialization of Commodities Markets, and Volatility & ETF Derivatives
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sircar
DMS-1211906

The investigator and his student and collaborators study some problems central to financial mathematics and mathematical economics. They develop analytical and computational methods for continuous-time nonzero sum games that arise in models of oligopolies where a small number of large players compete. Numerical solution of the associated Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman system of PDEs is challenging due to a degeneracy that develops because one player may not participate. The goal is to produce and analyze regularization or smoothing schemes that will be useful for many models in mathematical economics involving differential games with heterogeneous players. They also investigate the feedback mechanism from speculative commodities trading to understand market instabilities, and study volatility-related products through multiscale asymptotic analysis.

Energy markets are undergoing fundamental changes as production shifts from oil to natural gas towards renewable sources. The investigator analyzes these markets as oligopolies where the production costs and supplies are very different between different fuels or technologies. For example, an oil producer has relatively low costs but exhaustible reserves, while a producer from solar technology has high costs and essentially inexhaustible supply. He also studies how commodities markets have become more "financialized" over the past decade. This is due to an influx of speculative traders. The price movements of goods such as oil or wheat, which prior to the last decade were mainly governed by supply and demand of users of the commodity, are now much more similar to the more random movements of stock prices. Finally, the investigator looks at modern derivatives contracts such as volatility derivatives and leveraged exchange traded funds, in order to assess and quantify their risks, particularly in light of the recent financial crisis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impact of this project has been to better assess and manage market
volatility and market stability, especially in times of heavy turmoil like recently, as well as understand the structure of modern energy and commodities markets. Getting ahead of quantifying the risks of these products before their misuse leads to another calamity is a major responsibility of Financial Mathematicians.


The experience gained from the research strongly benefitted the investigator's teaching of financial mathematics classes at the undergraduate and graduate
levels at Princeton University, in particular the use of financial data and computational tools in the classroom, and for undergraduate Senior Thesis projects. The results were disseminated through classes, conferences and publications available online.

More specifically, the major outcomes of the project have been to develop mathematical models to analyze and understand i) energy markets, using and advancing tools of differential games; ii) the impact of financialization in commodity markets; and iii) risks inherent in modern derivative securities products such as options on leveraged ETFs, and volatility options.

A number of papers were completed and published. The PI gave many talks at seminars and international conferences on work related to this proposal. The first topic was worked on by an undergraduate student for his Senior Thesis, which then won a number of university prizes.

We looked at energy markets, in particular oil, which exhibited extreme volatility over 2014-16. We developed stochastic demand models which led to interesting mathematics, differential games in random environments. We investigated continuum mean field games, whose computational advantages can be exploited to provide insight into finite player games, motivated by oligopolistic energy markets. This was applied to try and understand the recent fall in oil prices where a game theoretic model can provide much insight. The resulting paper, to be published soon, is called ``Fracking, Renewables & Mean Field Games’’. This has had far-reaching extensions to understanding the dramatic decline of oil prices since June 2014, prompted by OPEC’s decision not to cut production in the face of competition from US fracking producers.

We also studied the problem of understanding implied volatilities from options written on leveraged exchanged-traded funds (LETFs), with an emphasis on the relations between LETF options with different leverage ratios.  This was analyzed in a multiscale stochastic volatility framework, using asymptotic techniques. Our empirical analysis of LETF data reveals some apparent biases in the leverage implied by the market prices of different products, long and short with leverage ratios two times and three times.

We further extended multiscale stochastic volatility methods in the following directions:  i) higher order in option pricing; ii) portfolio optimization; iii) transaction costs problems; iv) stochastic control problems involving filtering; iv) forward performance measures that involve ill-posed Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman partial differential equations. This will be developed into a book to be written in 2017.
